notes.text:
Siemens has released a new version for SINEC INS that fixes multiple vulnerabilities that could allow an attacker to read and write arbitrary files from the file system of the affected component and to ultimately execute arbitrary code on the device. In addition, this version also contains fixes for multiple vulnerabilities in underlying third party components.

Siemens has released an update for SINEC INS and recommends to update to the latest version.
notes.title: Summary

notes.text:
As a general security measure, Siemens strongly recommends to protect network access to devices with appropriate mechanisms. In order to operate the devices in a protected IT environment, Siemens recommends to configure the environment according to Siemens' operational guidelines for Industrial Security (Download: 
https://www.siemens.com/cert/operational-guidelines-industrial-security), and to follow the recommendations in the product manuals.
Additional information on Industrial Security by Siemens can be found at: https://www.siemens.com/industrialsecurity
notes.title: General Recommendations

notes.text: For further inquiries on security vulnerabilities in Siemens products and solutions, please contact the Siemens ProductCERT: https://www.siemens.com/cert/advisories
notes.title: Additional Resources

notes.text: Siemens Security Advisories are subject to the terms and conditions contained in Siemens' underlying license terms or other applicable agreements previously agreed to with Siemens (hereinafter "License Terms"). To the extent applicable to information, software or documentation made available in or through a Siemens Security Advisory, the Terms of Use of Siemens' Global Website (https://www.siemens.com/terms_of_use, hereinafter "Terms of Use"), in particular Sections 8-10 of the Terms of Use, shall apply additionally. In case of conflicts, the License Terms shall prevail over the Terms of Use.
notes.title: Terms of Use

notes.text: This CISA CSAF advisory was converted from Siemens ProductCERT's CSAF advisory.
notes.title: Advisory Conversion Disclaimer

notes.text: Multiple
notes.title: Critical infrastructure sectors

notes.text: Worldwide
notes.title: Countries/areas deployed

notes.text: Germany
notes.title: Company headquarters location

notes.text: CISA recommends users take defensive measures to minimize the exploitation risk of this vulnerability.
notes.title: Recommended Practices

notes.text: Minimize network exposure for all control system devices and/or systems, and ensure they are not accessible from the internet.
notes.title: Recommended Practices

notes.text: Locate control system networks and remote devices behind firewalls and isolate them from business networks.
notes.title: Recommended Practices

notes.text: When remote access is required, use more secure methods, such as Virtual Private Networks (VPNs), recognizing VPNs may have vulnerabilities and should be updated to the most recent version available. Also recognize VPN is only as secure as its connected devices.
notes.title: Recommended Practices

notes.text: CISA reminds organizations to perform proper impact analysis and risk assessment prior to deploying defensive measures.
notes.title: Recommended Practices

notes.text: CISA also provides a section for control systems security recommended practices on the ICS webpage on cisa.gov. Several CISA products detailing cyber defense best practices are available for reading and download, including Improving Industrial Control Systems Cybersecurity with Defense-in-Depth Strategies.
notes.title: Recommended Practices

notes.text: CISA encourages organizations to implement recommended cybersecurity strategies for proactive defense of ICS assets. Additional mitigation guidance and recommended practices are publicly available on the ICS webpage at cisa.gov in the technical information paper, ICS-TIP-12-146-01B--Targeted Cyber Intrusion Detection and Mitigation Strategies.
notes.title: Recommended Practices

notes.text: Organizations observing suspected malicious activity should follow established internal procedures and report findings to CISA for tracking and correlation against other incidents.
notes.title: Recommended Practices

references.summary: SSA-332410: Multiple Vulnerabilities in SINEC INS before V1.0 SP2 Update 1 - CSAF Version
SSA-332410: Multiple Vulnerabilities in SINEC INS before V1.0 SP2 Update 1 - TXT Version
SSA-332410: Multiple Vulnerabilities in SINEC INS before V1.0 SP2 Update 1 - PDF Version

cwe.name: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an OS Command ('OS Command Injection')

notes.text: In addition to the c_rehash shell command injection identified in CVE-2022-1292, further circumstances where the c_rehash script does not properly sanitise shell metacharacters to prevent command injection were found by code review. When the CVE-2022-1292 was fixed it was not discovered that there are other places in the script where the file names of certificates being hashed were possibly passed to a command executed through the shell. This script is distributed by some operating systems in a manner where it is automatically executed. On such operating systems, an attacker could execute arbitrary commands with the privileges of the script. Use of the c_rehash script is considered obsolete and should be replaced by the OpenSSL rehash command line tool.
notes.title: Summary

remediations.details: Update to V1.0 SP2 Update 1 or later version

notes.text: AES OCB mode for 32-bit x86 platforms using the AES-NI assembly optimised implementation will not encrypt the entirety of the data under some circumstances. This could reveal sixteen bytes of data that was preexisting in the memory that wasn't written. In the special case of "in place" encryption, sixteen bytes of the plaintext would be revealed. Since OpenSSL does not support OCB based cipher suites for TLS and DTLS, they are both unaffected.
notes.title: Summary

remediations.details: Update to V1.0 SP2 Update 1 or later version

notes.text: The OpenSSL 3.0.4 release introduced a serious bug in the RSA implementation for X86_64 CPUs supporting the AVX512IFMA instructions. This issue makes the RSA implementation with 2048 bit private keys incorrect on such machines and memory corruption will happen during the computation. As a consequence of the memory corruption an attacker may be able to trigger a remote code execution on the machine performing the computation. SSL/TLS servers or other servers using 2048 bit RSA private keys running on machines supporting AVX512IFMA instructions of the X86_64 architecture are affected by this issue.
notes.title: Summary

remediations.details: Update to V1.0 SP2 Update 1 or later version

cwe.name: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an OS Command ('OS Command Injection')

notes.text: A OS Command Injection vulnerability exists in Node.js versions <14.20.0, <16.16.0, <18.5.0 due to an insufficient IsAllowedHost check that can easily be bypassed because IsIPAddress does not properly check if an IP address is invalid before making DBS requests allowing rebinding attacks.
notes.title: Summary

remediations.details: Update to V1.0 SP2 Update 1 or later version

cwe.name: Inconsistent Interpretation of HTTP Requests ('HTTP Request/Response Smuggling')

notes.text: The llhttp parser <v14.20.1, <v16.17.1 and <v18.9.1 in the http module in Node.js does not correctly parse and validate Transfer-Encoding headers and can lead to HTTP Request Smuggling (HRS).
notes.title: Summary

remediations.details: Update to V1.0 SP2 Update 1 or later version

cwe.name: Inconsistent Interpretation of HTTP Requests ('HTTP Request/Response Smuggling')

notes.text: The llhttp parser <v14.20.1, <v16.17.1 and <v18.9.1 in the http module in Node.js does not correctly handle multi-line Transfer-Encoding headers. This can lead to HTTP Request Smuggling (HRS).
notes.title: Summary

remediations.details: Update to V1.0 SP2 Update 1 or later version

notes.text: A cryptographic vulnerability exists on Node.js on linux in versions of 18.x prior to 18.40.0 which allowed a default path for openssl.cnf that might be accessible under some circumstances to a non-admin user instead of /etc/ssl as was the case in versions prior to the upgrade to OpenSSL 3.
notes.title: Summary

remediations.details: Update to V1.0 SP2 Update 1 or later version

notes.text: Node.js made calls to EntropySource() in SecretKeyGenTraits::DoKeyGen() in src/crypto/crypto_keygen.cc. However, it does not check the return value, it assumes EntropySource() always succeeds, but it can (and sometimes will) fail.
notes.title: Summary

remediations.details: Update to V1.0 SP2 Update 1 or later version

notes.text: The llhttp parser in the http module in Node.js v18.7.0 does not correctly handle header fields that are not terminated with CLRF. This may result in HTTP Request Smuggling.
notes.title: Summary

remediations.details: Update to V1.0 SP2 Update 1 or later version

cwe.name: Improper Limitation of a Pathname to a Restricted Directory ('Path Traversal')

notes.text: An authenticated remote attacker with access to the Web Based Management (443/tcp) of the affected product, could potentially read and write arbitrary files from and to the device's file system. An attacker might leverage this to trigger remote code execution on the affected component.
notes.title: Summary

remediations.details: Update to V1.0 SP2 Update 1 or later version

cwe.name: Improper Limitation of a Pathname to a Restricted Directory ('Path Traversal')

notes.text: An authenticated remote attacker with access to the Web Based Management (443/tcp) of the affected product as well as with access to the SFTP server of the affected product (22/tcp), could potentially read and write arbitrary files from and to the device's file system. An attacker might leverage this to trigger remote code execution on the affected component.
notes.title: Summary

remediations.details: CVE-2022-45093: Disable the SFTP service of the affected product, if not required
Update to V1.0 SP2 Update 1 or later version

cwe.name: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in a Command ('Command Injection')

notes.text: An authenticated remote attacker with access to the Web Based Management (443/tcp) of the affected product, could potentially inject commands into the dhcpd configuration of the affected product. An attacker might leverage this to trigger remote code execution on the affected component.
notes.title: Summary

remediations.details: CVE-2022-45094: Disable the DHCP service of the affected product, if not required
Update to V1.0 SP2 Update 1 or later version
